subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
msgSnippet: And thanks for your detailed response. You are obviously not a slave to convention. It confirms one thing: people who actively use Quickscript, have every
messageBody:
Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth
And thanks for your detailed response. You are obviously not a slave to convention.

It confirms one thing: people who actively use Quickscript, have every need/right to change it and nuance it, since shorthand is first and foremost an intrapersonal means of communication.

I understand that even the professionals (court reporters) who use a suuposedly "common system" cannot 100% translate each other's work.  I even heard that one trial was dismissed because the reporter died before he could translate his notes - there was no legal record of the event possible!

Along the line of your "lightning" comments - (and to show you that we basically agree) I have had a peeve for a long time about the writing of "pity" in Ancrocles.  There it is piti. Which makes no sense to me at all. Try saying "pity" making the 2 vowels identical!  You feel like a comic butler in an Agatha Christie mystery. And just about as natural. 



kXrI oG!
--
- Robert McBroom
  Manager
  Onteora Mountain House
  Boiceville NY
  845-657-6233
